summary_comment: The professor is described as very hands-off, with learning primarily coming from online guides, and the professor's involvement being minimal. While one student found the professor to be kind and the workload manageable, another student found the class to be difficult, with heavy labs, readings, and papers, ultimately feeling that they learned very little.

Ratings.comment: very hands off, everything we learn is from online premade guides. The TA was good, the professor might as well have not existed. good luck, useless 4 page papers ever 2 weeks, with heavy labs and heavy readings. class was horrendous and hard and also learned nothing
Very kind professor. Workload is meh, it's can be lighter or heavier in certain weeks.

SEI.Subject: GEOG
SEI.Class Name: Spatial Simulation and Modeling in GIS

SEI.Subject: GEOG
SEI.Class Name: Spatial Simulation and Modeling in GIS

summary_comment: Becky is an enthusiastic and engaging professor who focuses on discussion-based learning and analysis of readings, making her classes intellectually stimulating. However, her grading can be stringent, particularly with her tough stance on assignments and her tendency to deduct points for minor issues, which can make achieving high grades challenging.

Ratings.comment: Becky is a passionate instructor, but as mentioned earlier, achieving a perfect score on assignments is impossible. She sticks with a single grade and applies it consistently throughout the semester. The material is engaging, and it's a relief not to have quizzes or tests, but her tough grading compensates for the absence of exams.

I took GEO 3801: Political Ecology. If you are not a geography major do not take her class for a GE. She is a really harsh grader and would constantly leave vague comments on what needed improved. never gave our 100%, always took off .5 of points. she wont like you if you arent into geography

Becky is amazing and GEO3801 is so interesting. No tests or quizzes, but there are discussion posts twice a week and optional attendance. There are also one page write ups due twice a month. What makes the course difficult is that some of the readings and academic journals are long and take time to comprehend. Easy B+, Hard A. Final is a project.

There are no tests or quizzes: instead, there are homework assignments mostly consisting of readings and short-to-medium write-ups. Attendance is extra credit. Prof. Mansfield is awesome, very passionate about what she does and what she teaches, flexible, and accessible outside of class. Not the easiest but definitely recommended for this GE.
Her classes are all discussion based, she doesn't like quizzes or exams so it's mostly analyzing readings. She is very laid back about late assignments as long as you communicate with her often.

Very decent professor. I enjoyed her classes when I did go but because attendance was extra credit/small part of grade I think many people skipped the class. The lectures were interesting and she is definitely enthusiastic about what she teaches, and I think your grade reflects the work you put in. Class is very discussion and reading based.
Probably the most intellectually exciting class I took at OSU even though it wasn't super hard

She is a very kind lady and a good professor, however her grading on quizzes is horrible. Very picky on responses no matter what the question is asking. One question asked about your thought on a topic and she only have half a point cause she didn't think the response was thoughtful enough.

Becky is incredible. She has a real interest in this topic and thoroughly enjoys teaching the students about the subject matter and getting them involved in discussions. Random activities for points but participation is not mandatory. Very relaxed and helpful.
Becky is a great professor! She's clear, helpful and seems to really care for the students. Class is easy and interesting. I definitely recommend this class!

Becky is great! I had her for 430 and 635. She is very passionate, approachable, and makes her classes incredibly enjoyable. She is a great resource and is always willing to talk with students. One of my favorites!

I was ill most of the quarter and she seemed pretty reasonable about participation grades. A large part of your grade is just being, mostly from pop quizzes. I averaged a B- on the midterm and final and I missed quite a lot of classes, though I did most of the readings. If you go to class and do the readings, this class will be easy.
very interesting material. communicated clearly-tied together well with course themes. very helpful. great teacher.

She was a decent teacher overall. The course material wasn't very interesting. A large part of you grade is based on being there every day. There are random pop quizzes, which can be annoying. If you are the type of person who never misses a class, this is the class for you. If you miss a class occasionally, you might not want to take it.
She was not very helpful in assisting me during a time of personal difficulty.  Her class was pretty basic and boring for a 400 level class.
Enjoyed the class
Great teacher.  Great interest in the students.  Really cares about the subject matter.  A rare find at OSU.
The course wasn't too hard for upperlevel.  If you show up youll do fine.  Dr. Mansfield is trys hard to be helpful and is a decent teacher.

"you've raised some excellent points, your sentences are clear, and I like what you've shown in your thesis.  you spent a lot of time proving your point and did so very well even though you took a difficult stance.  great job"  B+
Spent more time trying to control the class than teaching.  Way too wet behind the ears to be teaching an upper-level class.

SEI.Subject: GEOG
SEI.Class Name: Geographical Perspectives on Environment and Society

summary_comment: Dr. Fro's class is generally considered unorganized, with tests often focused more on attendance than content knowledge. Students find the grading criteria unclear and the class demanding, particularly for group projects which can be unevenly distributed depending on partner dynamics. While some appreciate her knowledge and encourage active participation, others describe it as one of the worst classes they've taken due to its disorganization and lack of approachability from the professor.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Fro is not a good professor. Her class is unorganized, and the tests are to see if you show up in class not if you know the content. To do well on the  group projects rely on if you have good partners otherwise you're stuck doing all the work. Be ready to read and study a lot. If you have taken other similar classes the class might be easier.
It was the worst class I've taken at OSU. It was highly unorganized, and the grading criteria weren't clear. Additionally, the professor was unapproachable.

Dr. Fro was so knowledgeable and emphasized class discussion. Kind of a tough grader, but most of the quizzes or the final were short answer. I didn't read a single reading assignment but I attended every lecture and still got an A. Take notes and review, know how to write essays, and lean on your groupmates for the midterm; you'll do fine.

Dr. Hice-Fromille is great. This class was a bit unorganized but she was happy to answer questions/ respond to emails. Make use of office hours (participation points) and ask questions!! Classmates did poorly because they didn't read readings or study for short answer style exams. She emphasizes understanding concepts, not memorization.

SEI.Subject: GEOG
SEI.Class Name: The Making of the Modern World

summary_comment: This professor demonstrates high-quality teaching, engaging students with interesting and relevant content in her first attempt at teaching the course. While the course title may have been misleading, focusing instead on global health, her approach was effective. She assigns practical, worthwhile projects and uses open-note exams, enhancing student learning. Her lectures are captivating, supported by relevant videos.

Ratings.comment: First time teaching this course, she made it interesting. The title was a bit misleading, with more of a focus on global health rather than 'life & death geography.' Each assignment was an interesting and worthwhile application of the content we covered, exams were open-note. Lectures are interesting and she incorporates videos relevant to content.

SEI.Subject: GEOG
SEI.Class Name: Life and Death Geographies: Global Population Dynamics

summary_comment: Alvaro is a passionate and effective teacher who simplifies complex concepts and offers substantial extra credit opportunities, making the class more manageable. His lectures, while sometimes lengthy, are generally enjoyable, and exams are online and relatively straightforward. However, some students find the mandatory attendance and unclear grade weighting to be drawbacks.

Ratings.comment:
> Super passionate about the material and is really good at simplifying decently complex concepts.
> Labs are easy even if you have a harsh grader.
> Textbook isn't mandatory but if you want to do well, you should be reading it along with his lectures; they complement each other well.
> Lots of extra credit (up to 6.5 points) and rounds up grades.

I really enjoyed Alvaro's lectures and learning the material even though it was outside of my major. Alvaro really enjoyed teaching the material and he always did he best to make it more interesting for all the students. The class had two online midterms and an online final which were easy.

Lectures are long and not that interesting but he does his best to try to make them interesting. Quizzes/tests are moderately difficult given the breadth of material and how granular some of the questions can be.

He's nice enough, and the class isn't hard. You can tell he likes his job, he just isn't the clearest about grades. The labs are boring but easy enough, they're just graded by the TAs. Discussion posts every week on a service that we had to purchase separately, and the grades in Carmen aren't the same as your actual grade.

There's only two things I dislike about his class: 

1) Mandatory attendance
2) Doesn't put official grade weights in until the end of the semester.

Otherwise, very funny and accommodating professor. Always in a happy mood. He really wants his students to pass. Exams are online and labs aren't that hard at all.

Very sweet professor and really cares about your learning if you participate and ask questions. Some exam questions are difficult but labs can bring your grade up. Some extra credit options, too! Make sure to take notes during lecture or get them from someone else

Alvaro offers extra credit, but you have to do tedious work that lasts MONTHS to even get 4 points of extra credit added to your grade. By no means is this class extremely difficult, but be prepared for long, hard, tedious work on labs and lecture notes in order to get a decent grade.

For a low level class this sucked. Labs were easy but grading would vary between TA's. Lectures would just be him rambling, weekly quizzes were incredibly difficult. Made us purchase a $25 service so he wouldn't have to grade disc. posts. Exams were multiple choice or t/f. Take a different science lab GE.
Midterm and Final could be hard at times but the rest of the class wasn't bad.

DONT TAKE THIS CLASS. Online labs are graded unfairly by differing TAs, causing me to have lower grades for same data/info as others for no reason. Also, he had a different grading scale/weight system as the one we are given and DID NOT INFORM US, making me think I had an A- the whole semester when I actually had a B-. Insanely frustrating.

This is an easy GE with a lab. This was online due to covid. The labs are just video recordings of TAs doing the lab and we fill out the lab manual. I got 100% on every lab so far. There are a lot of lecture videos to watch but take notes and you'll have the quiz and midterm answers. His lecture recordings are entertaining. Class was asynchronous.

DONT TAKE AS ONLINE COURSE! I had heard this was an easy science GE, which is easy to believe for an in-person class. However, the way the professor has set up his class is just not meant for pre-recorded, online lectures. It's very hard to follow, for the slides are mostly guides and him just talking. Also, labs online are VERY time-consuming.

Overall good professor. Go to class for extra credit with participation (TopHat) and pay attention. He explains slides well and tests are based off of them. Exams aren't that hard and he gives multiple ways to get extra credit. HIGHLY recommend if you need an easy science course as the lab was really easy too.

Nice guy, the slides were often guides and you HAD to go to class to get a full explanation but it was easy to follow if you tried to pay attention. Stay on top of lectures, take detailed notes while hes talking and read over notes after class and youll be fine. All finals/ midterms were decent, but dont fall behind, or it will be get hard.

He is an entertaining lecturer, he talks fast but seems to be pretty passionate about what he is teaching which makes the class better. Attendance is taken through TopHat, so unfortunately you have to attend class. Overall he's a good professor and very straight forward class.

The problem with his class is he talks too fast in lectures to be able to comprehend the information, and it's a mystery of what is on his tests. However he is very knowledgeable on the subject, has a sense of humor, and is good at answering people's questions.

The only things that go into your grade are labs, tests, and top hat. He gives extra credit, but some of it is a lot of work. Labs are crazy easy, but the tests are a tad difficult. I don't have a background in geography, so it is hard to grasp the concepts bc he goes really fast in lecture. I get more help from my TA than from him.

Alvaro's lectures are boring and a pain to sit through. While he uploads the slides to Carmen, they don't have words and aren't helpful. The lab portion was the only thing I enjoyed, as it was easy and saved my grade. I got 65% on midterm #2 and 78% on the final and passed the class with a B. Attendance is taken every day online, 3 times a week.

Really knowledgeable but not the best professor out there. He speeds through slides and goes off on tangents every other slide. The lab is SO easy. Exams are tough because its hard to retain any sort of information from him. I went to every single lecture and wouldve been better off not going. Chance for 5% added to your grade from extra credit.

This class has fairly difficult content but if you go to class and pay attention you will do totally fine. Dr. Montenegro is the nicest guy, makes jokes and is entertaining throughout class. The lab is unrelated to lecture but very easy.

Dr. Montenegro is a nice enough man and quirky individual, but his lecturing skills leave much to be desired. He tends to ramble on incoherently, and moves quickly through his slides. He is silly and often goes on side rants about Brazil or booze. There is almost no uniformity or communication between lab, which is taught by a TA, and his lecture.
So good so far!
He is really passionate about what he is teaching but for this being an 1900 level class it was alot harder than my upper level classes.

I thought that he was really clear during his lectures, and he gave a take-home exam, which was nice. We needed to do a few presentations, and a long paper at the end of the semester, but Dr. Montenegro was a very fair grader and gave great feedback.

One of the worst lecturers I've had. Extremely boring and not very helpful. Unless you really love environmental geography, I would STAY AWAY from this class. TA teaching lab treats you like little kids and you never know what is going on because the lectures don't coincide with lab. He got angry when we asked questions during review. Terrible prof

He's passionate about the topic he's teaching, but he has an accent that can be hard to pay attention to and the lecture's are boring if you're not that interested in the material. The labs were super easy. He takes participation for a grade randomly. He's can be pretty funny. Study for the midterms and you should be fine!

TAKE HIS CLASS! I stopped showing up to lecture after the mid term and still got an A. The labs were a joke. The woman who taught it treated us like kindergarten students, going over literally everything. His lectures are super boring, but much of the material is common sense environmental stuff. Plus, he's really funny. Accent is not bad either

Really easy material but it isn't presented very well. He doesn't teach the coinciding lab so the material is often times unrelated and there are errors in communication between the two professors. I wouldn't recommend this instructor.

Syllabus is very vague. Exam dates aren't given until a week before the exam. Reads directly from the slides during lecture and argues with himself in front of the class. I haven't learned a single thing from his course yet this semester and the lab work is riddled with errors in the data. I don't know how to prepare for this class.

SEI.Subject: GEOG
SEI.Class Name: Biogeography: An Introduction to Life on Earth

summary_comment: The professor for the 1-credit built-in lab in GEOG 1900 is a PhD student known for being a harsh grader who offers minimal guidance or support to students beyond a standard slide presentation at the beginning of each lab. Feedback is scarce, and there are indications that the professor may be disinterested in the role.

Ratings.comment:
> PHD student who taught the 1 credit built-in lab for GEOG 1900. 
> Harsh grader who doesn't particularly help out students during the lab or guide them very much apart from the boilerplate slide presentation that's given at the start of every lab. Not good at feedback either.
> Could be wrong, but seemed acutely disinterested in being there.

summary_comment: Professor Mark is knowledgeable about global climate change and geology but struggles with effective teaching methods, often relying heavily on lectures and slides that can be difficult to follow. Students appreciate the extra credit opportunities and the potential for building relationships through office hours, but many find the class challenging and the grading to be harsh, particularly for the group project and final paper. Overall, while some students find the material engaging and the professor passionate, others warn against taking the class due to its difficulty and poor support from both the

Ratings.comment: What I really liked about this class was not only the material, but the opportunities for extra credit! He had about 10 throughout the entire semester, and they were a great way to learn about other fields regarding climate change and about other professors/groups on campus.

I took Geography 2800 (Climate) and Earth Science 2122 (Geology), and I don't think I would've passed this class if I hadn't already taken these two. Professor Mark is clearly knowledgable about the subject of global climate change and the history of the Earth, but he does not teach it well.
Dr. Mark is my favorite professor. His teaching style is lecture heavy, so if you suck at taking notes, you will probably do bad. Also he puts his kids in his slideshows.

Not for slackers. If you did bad its probably because you didn't come to lecture. Skill issue. Final project was hard, but rewarding. If you go to his office hours, you will find it easy to build a relationship with him and he will help you with things you are struggling with. Also, ask him about research opportunities.

Dr. Mark is clearly very passionate about teaching and cares about his students. Class is usually pretty engaging, and sometimes he uses TopHat to gauge attendance (if you answer them right you get extra credit!). My least favorite part about the course was the group project. Some calculations in the course, but nothing that'll tank your grade.
do NOT take this class. just don't do it. Both the professor and the TA are very condescending and rude. They will not help you and will take points off for no reason.

Reads off of the slides with no opportunities to take notes. He uploads them,but they are confusing and full of graphs with no context. A big part of your grade is based on a group project that does not have clear instructions. The professor also seems intent on giving bad grades to prove a broad lesson about how hard climate change solutions are.

Very boring and is not understanding at all. If you have an interest in climate change prepare to never want to think about it again after. Grades come in very slow and the papers and group projects are harshly graded.

Lectures were an hour and 20mins of him talking through a google slide. Very boring and a waste of time. It was heavy reading and quizzes and midterm was hard.
He gave us hard math calculations with NO guidance or help at all. DO NOT RECOMMEND him or this class.

I took this class and I thought it was very challenging with all the math I had to do, and he really didnt give us step by instructions on how to actually solve the math problems. Plus, I had to write 2 5 page papers, including 1 with an annotated as my final, and there was also a group project.
So hard. Such dense reading and homework. Goes way too fast. Wouldn't recommend!

Dr. Mark helped me with a lot of stuff outside of class when I was considering changing my major. This class is very easy after taking AP Environmental Science, as most of the content overlaps. Labs aren't too hard. Tests are easy. Reading the textbook helped me follow his lectures which could get a little tiring.

This class wasn't bad, and I am not a science major. The content in class was honestly not that important. Pay enough attention to do well enough on the quizzes he has every once in a while (I got 3/4's and 4/5's usually). Put a good amount of effort into the group project and the final and you will be fine. This class is not a first priority class

He's okay. Lectures are very boring and just full of pictures of graphs so test material is based mostly off of things he says in passing. Not very hard at all though so as long as you pay attention and study a little you should be fine. Group project at the end though is very frustrating, little direction and enormous groups but graded easily.

Brian Mark is very passionate about weather and climate. His powerpoints were vague regarding definitions or concepts, he explained them more verbally. Teaches fast. Labs are easy, which is 30% of the grade, but tests are difficult. There are 4 exams and about 11 labs.  Content and tests were hard for a GE

Great guy, decent professor. You'd definitely be better off rereading his lecture notes and posted resources as he really doesn't clarify unless you ask. He is pretty available outside class and whenever you go to him in person he's very engaging and helpful.

Professor Mark did a very poor job on connecting the material form the lecture to that of the textbook, making it very hard to get a clear grasp on what was important to know for the three midterm exams, which basically carry your grade. This class was far too difficult for a GE, but the labs are not THAT horrible.

This might be an easy class for Earth Science majors, but it is definitely more tough if this is a course you need to take only to fulfill a requirement. I did not enjoy lectures or homework assignments, found many of them confusing. Overall the class was okay, although not very organized.

Good professor who wants students to succeed. His lectures are unnecessarily jargon-filled and unintelligible - they don't have a clear flow and professor doesn't distill lecture down to overarching principles - which makes material hard to digest. Accessible professor with a passion for what he does. Willing to work with you to help you understand

The class was interesting, but I swear he spent more time shamelessly plugging campus events and outside-of-class lectures by the geography department than he spent actually teaching the material. Never skip class, no matter how useless it sounds. I skipped once at the end of the semester and that was the difference between an A and a B.
Interesting class, learned a lot, BUT workload was a bit high for a GE course. Read 2-3 articles a week, group presentation, three midterms, 6 page term paper, researched team debate, BUT no final.

The material seems like it should be easy when you read it but his exams are ridiculous. The questions are so specific that it's impossible to study because you never know what you're going to be asked. Professor Mark seems nice enough but he is insanely obsessed with talking about himself. Just don't disagree with him and you'll be fine.
He explains things clearly and is dedicated to helping his students.

The class structure is pretty enticing as a student: no exams, minimal homework outside of group projects, and a 5-6 page research paper due at the end of the quarter. Dr. Mark was knowledgeable, helpful, and a lenient grader to boot. I highly recommend the class.

He is kind of hard to follow and at the beginning I was overwhelmed but he is a fair grader and it was manageable. Their was an essay style midterm, two homework assignments dealing with math,a research paper 3-5 pages single space, an annotated bibliography 2 pages, a research paper 10 pages at the end of the quarter, and a final in class present.

This class can seem really overwhelming at first if you're not a science major, but he's a fair grader and will be willing to help if you ask. There is no book to buy, all readings are online and all mid-term questions were given to the class one week before we took it. We had two homeworks, both requiring some basic algebra at most.

DO NOT take this class unless you are majoring in Geography, and have advanced knowledge of Global Climate Change and the equations to figure it out. He is not helpful in explaining things at all. I'm a political science major and he expects me to be an expert in science.

A good course if you like having a lot of interaction with other students/ discussion-based classes.  Projects and debates were a little vague, but the homework was straightforward and relatively easy.  Though you can expect more work in this class than most others, overall, it was pretty engaging and Dr. Mark instructs the class well.
Very interesting class, at times, a lot of readings; "field trips" are interesting if you enjoy the subject matter; Dr. Mark is very knowledgeable and nice.

He was a decent enough teacher.  The class does suck, though.  Fortunately, he didn't make us take a final like some of the other profs do, and he actually dropped one of our debates because the work load was really high.  The reading is totally not necessary to do - it's easy to just wing it.  And really, the homeworks weren't that bad...easy math

He is fine, nice guy, pretty willing to help and decent sense of humor. The class however, sucks. It's just way too much work/reading/math(?), 2 class presentations, 2 in class debates, 1 discussion lead, insanely hard homeworks, paper, etc. etc. Unless you're totally into a ton of work, don't take this class.

The hardest part of the class is waking up to go to it at 8 in the morning. Labs are really easy and if you don't understand part of it, him and the TA are very helpful. The midterms aren't too hard, I probably averaged an A on the labs and a C+ or B- on the midterm/final and ended up with a B+ in the class. Never bought the textbook.

I wouldn't say it was exciting, but it was the best science GEC I've taken at OSU. I didn't buy the book, took sparse notes, and still managed an A-. But the lectures were helpful. I'd definitely recommend this class with Dr. Mark.
Great professor. Has a lot of knowledge. Was very helpful. Lectures were boring but it was the subject not his fault. Overall a highly enthusiastic instructor who I would recommend.

Got C's on the midterms, but A's on the labs - ended up with an A- due to curve. The 8am class sucked, but go to lectures and read the book and you'll do fine.  Or skip half the classes, cram the night before a test, and you'll do fine, too.  Don't miss labs, they're easy and worth lots of points.

apparently this is an easy class since I got an A, but honestly i thought the material was confusing for a non-sciences major like myself. brian mark is a nice guy though, and he does his best to communicate the info clearly. the real saving grace here were the labs, which are ridiculously easy and short.
He is not a good person at all. I had some problems with him.Didn't get along. Lectures are boring exams are tricky.
I took his first class ever at OSU, Spring of 2004.  He is a great guy and cares about his student's. Take his class whenever you can. Tests are not very hard.
Dr. Mark is a great guy- get to know him at office hours.  Very helpful, and is willing to personally review exams.

He may seen unsure of himself at times, but definitely one of the best professors I've had. Very willing to help, whatever it takes, treats you like a human being, tests cover lecture material, and one of the nicest guys I've met at OSU.

summary_comment: Dr. Lin is highly regarded as an enthusiastic and passionate professor who prioritizes student learning and engagement. His classes are generally considered easy with open-note exams, low attendance requirements, and opportunities for extra credit. Students appreciate his care for the subject matter and his willingness to help during office hours, though some find his lectures repetitive or slightly boring.

Ratings.comment: Great Professor! Such a fun and enthusiastic guy. Would definitely take his classes again!

Laid back professor, prioritizes weekly assignments and a research project. Gives 3 midterms, only keeps 2 highest scores. Lectures can be a bit repetitive, but attendance is graded from time to time. Overall interesting person, and a wonderful professor.

Lin is passionate about his career and it shows during his lectures. There is no required textbook for this class. There are occasional attendance checks, so beware. The weekly lab assignments are easy. The exams are open note and your lowest score gets dropped. Definitely take this class if you are looking for an easy A.

Dr. Lin's geography class is perfect for the natural science ge. Exams were open note and he offered a 40 point extra credit assignment that would boost your grade 10%. Only downside was random 10 point attendance checks in the lecture. Overall super caring and a great professor.
Easy professor and a nice guy when you get to know him. Enjoyed talking to him during office hours! By far the easiest 4 credit class at OSU.

Dr. Lin is an amazing professor who cares very deeply about what he teaches. His lectures are very interesting...if you're going into the weather field. His exams were very straightforward, and class assignments were simple to follow.

Easiest class Ive taken at OSU. Lowest final and lab is dropped. 40 point extra credit assignment. Go to review lecture because the slides give you all of the answers for exams. The labs were pretty easy. The lectures were pretty interesting and quick. Take this class if you need a GE science credit. As long as you try a little you will get an A.

Wonderful professor! Tests are very easy and open note and everything on the test are in his slides. Lectures are a little boring but attendance is not mandatory. I would highly recommend Professor Lin to anyone!

Professor Lin cares about the success of his students. There were 3 exams, all open note (with the lowest grade dropped), there was a very easy 40 point bonus opportunity, and the only other assignments were the weekly labs (lowest grade dropped). He is making many important discoveries in the field, but he keeps things easy for the students.

I took the class for an easy science GE credit and was surprised at well the class was put together. Professor Lin cares about all of the students and makes the class easier through open note exams, dropping bad grades, and offering a big extra credit opportunity.

I took this class as a ge and I really enjoyed it. Professor Lin understands that this class is a ge and doesnt make it harder than it needs to be. So much extra credit too, I ended with over 100%. Exams were open note too. If you want an easy class, learn a little about weather, and have a professor that is kind and cares take this class.

Professor Lin is a great choice for GEOG1900- drops lowest lab grade and lowest exam score (I skipped the third exam and still finished with 103%). Also do the extra credit assignment, it adds 10% to your total grade! His lectures were pretty dry, but attendance was optional so as long as you look through the slides, you'll be fine.

Most of your grade is from labs, so if you show up to labs and try you will be okay. As a lecturer, he really cares about his students and will try to make it as easy as possible for you. He really likes teaching and helps outline the exams so you do well on the 3 exams. One is dropped.
The easiest class Ive ever taken. And, the professor is an amazing human being and he really cares about his students. I wish that all professors were like him.
Let's you drop your lowest exam grade, so you can skip the final. Easy weather diary that is 10% extra credit. Gives review power points for each exam, just need to study those and will do well.

He thinks he's a great teacher and I think he probably does care, but he basically just reads off the slides with occasional stories. Research is his number one priority, but he also does give nearly everyone an A. Drops a midterm out of the three. No final. 10 percent grade extra credit. Sometimes pop quizzes when attendance is low.

He is an interesting man who really cares about his students.  The class wasn't hard, the one midterm was so easy, but the final presentation is pretty long and demanding.  He can be boring, but he tries to relate to us and share personal stories and experiences.  I would take another class with him.
Easiest class I've ever taken, 10% extra credit for writing the weather for 60 days, 3 midterms and drops lowest grade
just attend the class and study the review powerpoint. You will get an A.

This class was one of the easiest classes I've ever taken. He drops your lowest lab, quiz, and midterm, plus he gives you the option to complete a weather diary for a 10% bonus to your grade. All you have to do is show up because there are pop quizzes but the quizzes are 2-4 questions multiple choice
His lectures are really boring. But exams are easy and there are extra credits. You can even drop one midterm.

Professor Lin's class is very clear-cut in terms of what you can expect for the semester, as he drops lowest pop quiz, lab, and midterm. MANY opportunities for extra credit, although there is no curve. He loves what he does, and seems very passionate about the weather and nature. It's fairly easy if you go to class and labs.

Lectures are boring, as he reads straight from the PPs that he posts online. But have to go to lecture bc you never know when he is going to give a pop quiz- Worth 20% of your grade.. Midterms are easy, he highlights all things that will be asked (In red) in PPs (only thing u need to study). And he gives easy10% EC- Record 60 days of the weather.

summary_comment: Dr. Liu is a clear and straightforward professor who emphasizes clear expectations and straightforward assessments. Students find his classes manageable, especially for those with prior statistical or coding knowledge, and appreciate the availability of resources like prerecorded lecture videos and detailed study guides. While some find the class structure and lab work beneficial, others suggest supplementing the provided materials for a deeper understanding.

Ratings.comment: This class will be a breeze if you have any stats or coding background. Everything is open note and the TA was always helpful but I never needed help beyond that so I can't speak to how helpful Dr. Liu is. I only saw him on his prerecorded lecture slides videos, never in person or on zoom. However, there is minimal actual map use or design.

Very clear expectations of students, learned a lot of useful information. I sometimes had trouble following the lecture vocabulary used, as my stats background isn't great, but with the textbook reference, it was no problem. Study beyond just the study guide provided for exams though, as other things will appear.

This class was hybrid, so the lectures were posted online each week with an in-person recitation. This made it hard to ask questions, but Dr. Liu was always available outside class. The structure of the class was great, labs had clear directions, and resources to prep for the midterm and final were posted on Carmen. Would take again.
I enjoyed this class. His expectations from you are obvious, and he is very clear on all the criteria. The assignments do help on tests, and he is very accommodating for disabilities.

Easy class of statistics. Labs are short and easy but useful, and you'll get a good grade. Exams matters, but as long as you do homework well, you'll get A. Exams contain essay and short answer questions about term concepts, and they are open note!

Dr. Liu makes things very clear and as long as you attend class, pay attention to the labs and get everything turned in on time, you will likely do well. His exams are fair and everything is kept straight forward.

Pay attention to the labs and you'll do good.  Group projects depends on the team.  Overall one of really good professor, ready to help you when you need it.  Also, attendance matter - normally his classes its 20% of the grade.
his exam and midterms preparations are misleading. be sure to read everything.

summary_comment: Dr. Liu is highly knowledgeable in dynamic meteorology but struggles with simplifying complex material and effectively communicating concepts, making lectures and notes difficult to follow. While his exams are straightforward and fair, and he ensures everyone passes through curving grades, his teaching style is challenging for many students.

Ratings.comment: Does not know how to simplify material nor tie it into concepts. Extremely difficult to decipher notes and handwriting. Is late to almost every class, his homework reviews are never explained and it is assumed you are on equal level of mathematical capability of a graduate student. Avoid if possible.

Dr. Liu is very knowledgeable in Dynamic but it was difficult to stay on top of the lecture if you did not attend the class. The class only has homework and exams and both are straight forward and fair.

Dr. Liu is extremely knowledgeable in dynamics. However, when communicating it to students, it can be too complex at times to understand. Homeworks and tests are straightforward and fair, but are quite time consuming. Office hours are of great help.

Dr. Liu is very knowledgeable in Dynamic Meteorology, however he is not a good teacher. He unfortunately can not simplify the material enough so that students can understand it. His exams are straight forward and fair. He also curves so that everyone passes the course.

summary_comment: The professor's teaching quality is generally poor, characterized by dull and disorganized lectures that are difficult to follow, even with significant effort. Students consistently complain about harsh grading, particularly from TAs, and find the class unengaging and unnecessarily challenging.

Ratings.comment: No matter how much effort you put into focusing in this class, it remains difficult due to the dull and disorganized instruction provided by the professor. Additionally, there are four assignments, each accounting for 16% of the total grade, and the TA are very harsh grader!

The most god awful boring professor I have ever had to sit through. Unfortunately attendance quizzes are random as well as group activities, if those did not exist 95% of the class would never show up. Avoid this class if possible. Gods speed

Prof. Le does a great job boring me in the class every time. She just reads off the slides and is completely dry while doing so. Not to mention the class is quite useless. She also grades in class participation ridiculously hard and sets high stand

Dr. Lee is one of the worst professors I had to take at OSU, her lectures are so boring. Not to mention that she grades TOUGH. She rarely gives participation credits. You show up to class, you do your task in class yet SHE BARELY gives you credits. She has nonsense HIGH STANDARDS for absolutely nothing. FIND ANOTHER PROFESSOR AND SAVE YOURSELF

a harsh grader that thinks she is the only one that knows everything, please do yourself a favor and don't take this class with her. She doesn't care about her students at ALL. It feels like she is there to make everybody's life harder. She reads from the slides and that's it.

She really cares about teaching and I enjoyed this class a lot because of that. Very interesting material in my opinion and the class work was extremely manageable. Probably spent 1 to hours a week on this class.

Dr. Le is great. The class was well organized and she showed current examples for the topics we learned. I really enjoyed the Map of the Day because it was usually about a problem that was relevant for the time. The assignments were also very well laid out (deadlines, instructions, etc.).

I have a really hard time with statistics and Professor Le really helped me learn. Attendance accounted for only 7% so it should be fine if you miss some sessions. I did think the final project was pretty hard, but other than that, a great class.

Dr. Le works her hardest to make the concepts difficult and convoluted. Material is not complicated in nature or hard to understand in other data analysis classes, but here it is awful. Assignments are unrelated to material, and instructions are too vague. Do not take classes with Dr. Le.

The textbooks have no correlation to the lectures, the lectures are boring and it's difficult to understand what is important. Attendance is a must. The assignments are sometimes outdated and poorly constructed. There are reading quizzes that are medium difficulty. Communication is poor. If you are not interested in data analysis stay far away.

summary_comment: Joel Wainwright is an exceptionally knowledgeable and passionate professor, highly respected by many students for his deep insights into Marxist theory and political philosophy. However, his classes are demanding, with extensive reading and strict criteria, which can be stressful and challenging. While some students find his lectures and discussions inspiring and deeply rewarding, others struggle with the ideological focus and lack of technological allowances in his classes.

Ratings.comment: I've taken this professor twice and he can be a very stressful professor to have. I don't like how he doesn't allow us to take notes on our laptops because he thinks that it's "distracting" and he has very stringent criteria for our research papers. He's also a Marxist, and can seem very biased, too. (I'm not a conservative, BTW).

You will learn about Marxism whether you are ready for it or not.   Notwithstanding the left leanings of his teachings, Joel is an excellent lecturer and passionate about his profession.  Probably the best professor that I have had at OSU since entering the Program60 in the Spring of 2020. There is some very difficult material in this class.

Terrible class and professor. 100 points in the entire class. Joel was out most of the semester, but was always up in the air about class and assignments. His lectures are NOT uploaded to Carmen, so don't miss class. Talks only about his own political views rather than teaching the class the required material. No technology in class. Have fun...

Philosophical conversations bore me to death, fell asleep during the rare times I showed up. I had to take it for my major, though. I didn't really go to class and only came for the exams. Every lecture is based on the readings, so just read them and you'll be fine.

I took Prof Wainwright's first year seminar on climate change and I absolutely loved it. It was a pass fail class and only one credit hour, so easy, but nonetheless great. He is so smart and I loved all the readings we had this semester. He inspired me to add a minor in sustainability, and I plan to take another one of his courses in the future,

I got obsessed with this course. I read close to 400 pages of political theory as a sophomore, and let me tell you, not a good idea. The ideological, socialist narrative he stresses to his students has its perks for sure, but it is so ideological that you have to be very careful in how you interpret it. Just be careful.

The single hardest class I've taken, but so worth it. Everything everyone says here is true. He is by far the most brilliant, knowledgable professor I've ever had, although the class is crazy difficult. You'll read a lot but learn even more. Last class made me bawl like a baby -- incredibly inspiring professor.

I love Joel Wainwright more than I love my parents. No but honestly, he is beyond inspiring. He might be a bit narcissistic, but honestly, he kind of deserves to be. He is so smart it will drive you crazy, but he also engages with students-- especially those who show up having done the reading, inquisitive, and invested. best ever.

5700 is my favorite class so far and Wainwright is brilliant. Left lectures with my mind blown every time; really changed how I view the world. Wainwright challenges his students and the onus is on you to keep up with the very theoretical material, but he is accessible. Tests and one paper are the only grades. Can't recommend highly enough.
A brilliant professor with magnetic lectures to which you need to pay close attention for more difficult exams than OSU's average professor.

Dr. Wainwright is by far one of my favorite professors. I had his lecture on climate change and he really knows his stuff. Hes very easy to talk to and is super kind. If he taught all of my classes I would certainly enjoy college much more.

Professor Wainwright is the best teacher I have had at OSU! Each of his lectures is like its own stand alone, extended Tedtalk. Also the work isn't too too hard. If you pay attention to the lectures and write decently, you don't really have to read anything.

the only one that comparatively harder than him could be a chemistry professor though I have to admit that he's truly brilliant. but the class' been way too difficult. but it deserves your time. I only expect a C or B in this course.

The best thing I can tell you about Dr. Wainwright is that everyone who has said anything on here is right. He is a divisive but passionate academic who is somewhat disconnected from the student experience, but that matters, because it's obvious he would rather reinvent that experience, anyway. He's a good guy, but be ready for a tough class.

Honestly the best professor I've ever had. He truly cares about what he is teaching and passionate about the topics. He was extremely well prepared and knowledgeable about the topics, probably the smartest teacher I've ever had. He gives amazing lectures and I would love to have him again for another class. Great guy.
Really good class, but DO NOT MISS and read the damn readings. Our TA was an easy grader so I lucked out. Good lectures, always leaves you mind blown.

Dr. Wainwright is probably the best quality professor I've ever had and is a very good lecturer. However, I felt like I was being led to believe in Communism and that pseudo-Marxist revolution would be a good idea. Don't drink all the cool-aid, but he is insightful so take it for what it's worth. He cares about his work and is a unique professor.

The exams are extended response and you have to know readings pretty well. The exams are intimidating but doable. The two papers aren't bad, short and easy. Joel is really awesome. He stays behind every class and talks to the students, answering complex questions and helping clarify things. I usually end up staying 30+ minutes after just to listen.

There are plenty of readings in the class, however he delves into most of them during class time so I didn't feel it necessary to read much. (I was only aiming for Bs though, which I got). He gave great insights about the state of world affairs and I solidly recommend it for all IS majors at OSU.

teaches an outdated Material and views no longer applied in development and economics..  The most recent data he uses is from early 90s. Clearly doesnt respect if a personal point of view is different from his. Expects to read 200 pages a day and doesnt provide  study guide or review at all.

Geography of Development was the best class I've had at OSU. I left every lecture with a 'mind blown' feeling, thanks to the brilliant lectures of Wainwright. That being said, I wish I had taken a pre-req beforehand for baseline knowledge about development. I was graded harshly on the paper--Joel was inaccessible for help when asked, no office hrs.
Dr. Wainwright is clearly passionate about his work. He engages students and challenges everyone to think critically and defend their beliefs. This was one of my favorite geography classes so far!

This class should have prereqs. It was my first Intstds class, and I didn't do well. He expects you to walk in with a full background in diplomacy and give him highly theoretical essay exams. Read and study all you want, but if you don't have a strong background in the stuff already, you won't get more than a C.  Also, he's pretty rude to students.

This class is phenomenal.  Most inspiring teacher that I've ever had. The class is not easy, but this is college --you should be challenged-- and that's exactly what this class will do to you. Though he may seem intimidating to talk to- when talking to him one on one he was very helpful. You'll be pushed to think critically in this class.

Lectures were interesting but the reading load was ridiculous (50-100 pages each class). 3 exams and 2 papers, grades EXTREMELY tough. Pretty much impossible to get above a B in this class. He is extremely condescending and strict. If you turn in the paper on the day its due, but after he begins lecture, it is considered a day late. Avoid him!!

If u can avoid him do so at all costs. He thinks he's teaching middlehigh schoolers. He is rude, ignorant&doesn't grade u on the material learned, he grades on whether u can write a "good" essay or not. Doesn't make and effort to work with students. No technology policy. No need to do the readings if u come to class. Worst classteacher at OSU

Dr. Wainwright is a great lecturer and encourages students to think for themselves. However, he often pushes his beliefs onto students by presenting them in one-sided arguments. Attendance is not mandatory but if you don't do the readings (there are a lot) and attend class you will fail. This class is not easy, a B+  is probably equivalent to an A

Incredible professor, highly recommend this fascinating class. His lecture are very engaging and he really knows his stuff. Lots of reading but it's interesting stuff and you can skip reading now and then and be fine. Test are completely essay based and there are a few short writing assignments. A very fair grader.
Dr. Wainwright is by far the best professor I've had at Ohio State. He is truly inspiring. The class is not "easy", but it is more than worth taking.
Professor Wainwright is a truly inspiring teacher, one of the best I've ever had.  The class was absolutely fascinating.

If you pay attention in class and take decent notes that's all you really need for the exams. The readings are helpful but ultimately just optional on top of his lectures, also the few short papers are directly based on the readings but you get to choose which one you write about.

One of the best professors I've ever had. Extremely smart and knows his stuff. The class is hard and you have to attend every class or you will be lost. I hope to be able to take another class with him in the future.

At the end of the semester our class gave him a round of applause. I have never seen that before. He is the best college teacher I ever had. Tests are hard, but if you don't take his class you miss out on one of the best teachers you ever seen.

The material is interesting, but the grading is insane. Don't take this class if you care about your GPA--especially if it's only for a GE. A lot of people liked him, but I thought he was a bit of a snob.

Exams are brutal (essay based; study method=rereading all notes and readings and hope you remember the detail he asks about), reading is insane, but I probably learned more from this class than any other I have taken so far. Dr. Wainwright is awesome and I don't regret taking this class at all, even if my grade wasn't where I wanted it.
Incredible professor. You should take this class!

It was an interesting class, the first part was definitley more interesting than the second. You will have a TON of reading to do, so make sure you don't take other classes that have a lot of reading. There's two papers to write that aren't bad, but his exams suck, they are all essay-based. Wainwright is cool for the most part.

This was one of my most memorable courses at Ohio State.  This course can be challenging, but Joel is a very engaging speaker - each class period is interesting and thought-provoking.  He encourages discussion, so try not to be shy.  Attendance is not mandatory, but it's in your best interest to attend every lecture.
Professor Wainwright is probably the best professor I've had my college career. He is very challenging but extremely helpful. He really knows his stuff. I highly recommend his class
Professor Wainwright is one of the best professors I've had at OSU. He does a great job of explaining things and is a phenomenal speaker. I would definitely take another class taught by him.

Amazing professor. Sometimes he comes across as a bit pretentious but without doubt the best professor I have ever had. His lectures are impeccable. Class is not easy but it will be the most fun and engaging class you'll have your whole college career. Oh and when the weather is nice he lectures out by mirror lake!
Easily the best course I have taken at OSU! Exams are challenging but fair and he is willing to help with the research paper (recommended some great sources).
Awesome professor but extremely hard grader. Learned more in this class than any other class I have taken at Ohio State.
The best professor I've had at Ohio State.  His class is a challenge but you'll learn a lot!

Best teacher I've ever had. One of few classes that actually makes you feel smarter. He is a great speaker and excellent at explaining things. He is also very patient when people don't understand something.

Admittedly, he is a good teacher.  But you should make sure that you agree with his point of view.  Even if you don't, however, you can simply amend your ideas and writing to his liking and you'll do fine grade-wise.

Hardest class I've taken thus far. But totally worth it. FIrst class I've taken where I feel like I've actually become smarter. I learned so much and even though the first couple weeks were hard to get through, the content becomes so applicable to life and infinitely useful. TAKE THIS CLASS.
Smart, intelligent, and critical. Speaks in clear English and sounds like a public speaker at times. As long as you read, you should be able to pass the class.

Easily the best professor I have had at OSU thus far. Wainwright's lectures are extremely compelling and makes you want to learn, but expect at least 75 pages of challenging reading each week. He is so good at teaching Gee and Archie Griffin interrupted our last class to give him a prestigious faculty award. No joke.
He is by far one of the most passionate professors at OSU. He makes you want to go to class everyday and learn so much. Class is hard for a 200 level but its worth it! (Eye-Candy)
By far the best professor at OSU, he is so passionate about what he teaches and just makes you want to learn so much!
Easily the best teacher I've had at OSU. Class is challenging (lots of reading) but Wainwright makes it interesting and keeps your attention. Wish all my professors were as good as him.
I adore this man. Absolutely brilliant lecturer. Increadible intelligence. You will not regret taking a class with him (unless you want something easy)
One of my favorite professors of all time. Assigns a lot of readings, but I always look forward to class!

He is one of the best professors at OSU period.  His classes are not easy but they are extremely interesting and you will be able to think more critically and have a better understanding of how the world works.

the class is challenging and WAINWRIGHT is one the best teacher i ever had at OSU.but he is very stingy in grading.i don't know if it is him or his T A Seung that is doing the grading, they need to do a better job
Tough class, but very interesting. he's a very intelligent man just trying to make you think critically. I genuinely feel smarter after taking this class. Highly recommended.

Complaint or criticism of the modern world is unfounded without examination and understanding of how it came to be. The making of the modern world is clearly and enthusiastically unpacked by this fantastic professor. Always willing to help, even when it came to extending office hours, Joel is all I expect and desire of a professor and more. Enjoy!

I really enjoyed this class. The reading could be confusing or boring but he cleared everything up really well in the lectures. He's a great lecturer and made it fun! I will be taking another class with him.
Witty...interesting...He may very well be a geo genius. Overall, one of my favorite profs at OSU.
Awesome personality, very intelligent, phenomenal class!
Super interesting and fun
valuable resource.. dorky

I took both 630 and 642. Both courses require a lot of reading (close to 1,000 pages), but the material is very interesting and original. Be prepared to work very hard, but you will get a lot out of the class. The professor is easy to talk with, and has a genuine interest in working with students.

To get a good grade A LOT of reading is required as well as regular class attendance. As long as you write the general large ideas covered in class, you'll do ok on the exams. A 20 pg research paper is required as well & as long as you have a clear thesis & put thought into it you'll do fine.

SEI.Class Name: The Making of the Modern World

summary_comment: Professor Woodworth is highly regarded for his dedication to student success and accessibility outside of class. His classes are known for being challenging, with a focus on readings and writing, and he encourages active participation through discussions. While the material can be dense and the lectures sometimes dry, students appreciate his passion for the subject matter and his willingness to help them understand complex topics.

Ratings.comment: Class was heavy with readings and writing, but no tests for a 4 credit class. Watching movies is also a lot of time because you often have to rewatch it. A little boring at times, but is super knowledgable and willing to work with you outside of class.

I took 2100, Professor Woodworth created lectures on the spot, and rambled quite a bit. He is very interested in Taiwan/China relations & that is definitely a strong theme in the class. Lots of high level reading assigned for every class, was tedious. 4 assignments including exams total. Do the readings, come to class and its an easy A.
Weekly one page paper, exams, and a book report, but overall a pretty easy class and SUCH a nice guy!!! Really enjoy having him as a prof.

Very nice guy but his voice is super boring so lectures aren't the easiest to focus on. He does really care about the subject and his students though and makes the semester very pleasant. There is a one page paper due every week and a couple exams, but as long as you put in the effort it is possible to get an A

He really cares about his students success and understanding. This class was asynchronous so it's obviously lecture heavy but the discussions allow you to interact and give your point of view on the topic. Lectures are a little dry but interesting at the same time.

Dr. Woodworth has been one of the best professors I've had at OSU. While he does make you work for your grade, he is very accessible outside of class and is willing to help in any way. There is a reading response almost every week and the tests were a take-home which was nice. Class was always interesting and thought-provoking!

Dr. Woodworth has been one of the best professors I've had at OSU. While he does make you work for your grade, he is very accessible outside of class and is willing to help in any way. He's very personable and makes an effort to get to know his students, and is very passionate about what he teaches. Class was always interesting and discussion-based

Max is absolutely one of the best professors I have had at the OSU. As an international student, I felt REALLY overwhelmed and the readings seemed tough. However, I have not learnt that much in one GE class before. He is very caring and all of his lectures are super-informative. Never skip a class because his super long exams are based on them.

Max is one of the most fantastic Professors I've ever had. I took his Urban China course, which is done seminar style. Typically we had around 50 pages of readings each week for the class discussion, of which he does an exceptional job at administering and teaching. The final paper is worth the majority of the course grade. 10/10 would recommend.

my main issue with this class is that we were graded on so few things and received no feedback. we just received seemingly arbitrary grades for assignments with literally 0 comments. the class itself was not uninteresting, but i could have definitely found a better social science GE. not the easiest A, but do the readings and you'll probably be ok.

Best professor I've had in college. From his lectures, you can see how truly passionate he is about what he teaches, making it a lot easier to get into what he's teaching. Made me change my major after taking my first class with him. Just do the assigned readings and he'll take care of the rest.
Concise lectures with good reading material to supplement. He did not make us get a text book, which is amazing. So good.

One of my favorite professors ever. He is very knowledgable and passionate about development but also challenges students to think for ourselves about issues. Provides many points of view to a very tricky and controversial topic. Reading and writing heavy but very enjoyable class. I learned a lot and am very glad I took the class.

Dr. Woodworth is an awesome professor. He is extremely smart and knows a TON about China. He structures his classes in a way that is conducive to learning and no busy work. His classes are not overly difficult and he is always willing to meet outside of class to help students. Put in a little effort, do the readings, and you'll enjoy his class.

Dr. Woodworth is a very knowledgeable guy. Lectures were very interesting, although a little boring at times. There are five 3-5 paged papers graded by the TA that took a fair amount of time. There are a lot of readings that he expects you to keep up with, and test questions come from the book and readings. Midterm and final both easy as he gives a study guide. Very simple and up front guy

Knowledgeable and smart, lectures were very interesting though material was pretty easy. Excessive amount of work with a midterm, final, and five 3-5 page papers. Also assigns long readings and expects you to print them out and bring them to class and gets super passive aggressive when no one does because everyone reads them on their laptops.

Obviously very knowledgeable and passionate about what he teaches, makes lectures interesting. There's 5 essays throughout the semester mainly graded by the TA so it can be considered difficult, but they are 3-5 pages so if you are closer to the 5 page range you're good. Test questions are straight from the readings/textbook, so keep up with those.

Dr. Woodworth is an intelligent professor who is very knowledgeable in his area of study. He is clearly interested in what he teaches, and he enjoys helping students who are willing to ask for feedback. Great prof, expect a fair amount of reading, but most quizzes draw from these readings, and if not, they provide great perspective for students.

I changed my major after taking this class. A lot of work, but you learn a lot and he's not only a smart guy but also is really passionate about what he teaches. He values students that want to actually learn not just get an A.

His class is absolutely inspiring. A lot of discussion on economics issue and he always gives positive feedback. I really like the way he organized his classes and some deep insights into many problems. But there are a lot of readings out of class and be ready to write!
great teacher, a lot of readings but easy grade if you read

He's a really interesting professor. You should probably keep up with the reading and do it carefully as the tests draw straight from the text book. There are super annoying homework assignments. Exams are slightly difficult, but an easy A in the class if you try.

He's a nice guy and the class is interesting. There's a ton of reading and you have to write papers on the readings twice a week. He doesn't give a lot of feedback on assignments, so you have to go to his office hours and ask for help if you're not getting the grade you want. If you do the work, you will definitely pass.
good prof, interesting lectures. I learned a lot!
Ok class. Harder than I expected.  I went to every class and paid attention but some of the homework assignments and tests seemed a little difficult.
He's the nerdy kind of hot.

Exams are difficult! You should read your book VERY carefully! Attendance is mandatory even if lectures help little for exams. UNDERSTAND your BOOK is crucial. Weekly homework(Question set), and several writing tasks is the easiest way to get points in this course, which really helps you to get A(avoid pts deducted by these stuffs or impossible A

Extremely boring, very pretentious, and not really very clear about what is expected from assignments. Material is dull, long, and dense. In total, I learned very little about what his readings had to do with "Making the Modern World", but  it's not hard to get a good grade.

Prof. Woodworth is a great professor, who is passionate about what he teaches and about the students he teaches. Class is pretty straightforward bi-weekly 300-500 word reading summaries, a group project and final paper make up your grade.
